title: 114_hr3102
content: The "Airport Access Control Security Improvement Act of 2015" is also known as the Act. It amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 by adding a new section for risk-based screening of employees at airports. The Administrator must establish a risk-based screening model for airport employees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This model will ensure only authorized individuals access secure airport areas and immediately deny entry when authorization is revoked. The Administrator must establish a risk-based screening model for airport employees within 180 days of the Act's enactment, considering factors like employee access to secure areas and reducing entry points. The Administrator must establish a risk-based screening model for airport employees within 180 days of the Act's enactment, considering factors like employee access to secure areas and reducing entry points. In consultation with airport operators, the Administration will create a randomization plan for screening at entry and exit points at airports to maximize the deterrent effect of screening efforts. Additionally, a review of disqualifying criminal offenses for aviation security will be conducted within the specified timeframe. Regulations will be reviewed to determine the appropriateness of offenses for denying airport employees unescorted access to Secure Identification Display Areas, considering the current aviation security threat environment, including terrorism insider threats. The review will assess the need to tailor disqualifying offenses to address these threats and evaluate the security benefits and challenges of identifying patterns of offenses. The Administrator will review regulations to assess the appropriateness of offenses for denying airport employees access to Secure Identification Display Areas, considering the current aviation security threat environment, including terrorism insider threats. This includes evaluating the need to tailor disqualifying offenses and assessing security benefits and challenges in identifying offense patterns. Additionally, a redress process will be provided for employees facing adverse employment decisions within 180 days of the enactment of this section. The Secure Identification Display Area badge program will undergo changes subject to notice of proposed rulemaking. The Administrator will brief Congress on the aviation security risk-based review findings. The Administrator will review airport-issued identification media auditing procedures within 120 days of enactment. The review will assess the effectiveness of auditing programs at domestic airports and consider implementing biometrics standards for identity verification. The Administrator will establish a program for airport badging offices to use E-Verify to check eligibility to work in the US for applicants accessing secure airport areas within 180 days of enactment. The Administrator will establish a process to transmit applicants' biometric fingerprint data to OBIM's IDENT for vetting and conduct a data quality assessment to ensure completeness and accuracy of credential application data. Upon completion, the Administrator will brief relevant congressional committees on the results. The Administrator will establish a nationwide program for anonymous reporting of airport security violations and a centralized database of employees with revoked badges for non-compliance with security requirements. The Administrator will conduct an updated review of airport access controls and submit a study on employee screening within 180 days. Individuals can have their names removed from the database if mistakenly entered. The Administrator will conduct a cost and feasibility study of airport employee entry and exit points at Category I, II, and X airports. This study includes requirements for secure doors, surveillance video recording, and advanced screening technologies like magnetometers and explosives detection canines. The study will analyze the costs of employee screening at airports that screen all employees entering secure areas. It will include costs of entry and exit points and compare costs based on whether the implementation was done by the Administration or airports. The Comptroller General of the United States will assess the quality and reliability of the study on employee screening costs at airports. A report will be submitted to relevant committees within 60 days of receiving the study. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new item in the table of contents after section 1601. Passed by the House of Representatives on October 6, 2015.
